questions.question: Question 1: At what level does the adult larynx end?
questions.explanation: In adults, the larynx ends at lower border of C6. It extends from C3 to C6 vertebra.

questions.question: Question 2: What is the average final anteroposterior diameter of glottis in women?
questions.explanation: The average anteroposterior diameter of the glottis is 26mm in women and 36 mm in men. Glottis, also known as rima glottidis, is the narrowest part of the laryngeal cavity. It is formed by: • Anterior 2/3rd by membranous cords • Posterior 1/3rd by vocal processes of arytenoids.

questions.question: Question 3: What is the primary function of the larynx?
questions.explanation:
The primary function of the larynx is to protect the airway from ingested food and aspirated 
materials. This is done by the sphincteric action of the larynx. Other important functions are: • Respiration • Phonation • Building up of intra-thoracic pressure.

questions.question:
Question 4: The presence of which structure is responsible for infants to be able to breathe 
simultaneously while suckling milk?
questions.explanation:
The high position of the larynx in infants allows simultaneous breathing while feeding. 522 
Sold by @itachibot The infant’s larynx is positioned high in the neck, level of the glottis being opposite to C3 or C4 at 
rest and reaches C1 or C2 during swallowing. The high position allows the epiglottis to meet the 
soft palate and make a nasopharyngeal channel for nasal breathing during suckling. The milk feed passes separately over the dorsum of the tongue and sides of the epiglottis, thus 
allowing breathing and feeding to go on simultaneously.

questions.question: Question 5: Which embryological structure develops into the epiglottis?
questions.explanation: The epiglottis develops from the hypobranchial eminence which is a part of the 4th arch.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following comprises the larynx?
questions.explanation: The larynx has 3 unpaired and 3 paired cartilages. Unpaired: • Thyroid • Cricoid • Epiglottis Paired: • Arytenoid • Corniculate • Cuneiform.

questions.question:
Question 7: The lateral x-ray of an elderly man shows calcification of the laryngeal cartilages. Which of 
the following is unlikely to be involved?
questions.explanation:
Epiglottis is unlikely to be calcified as it is made up of elastic cartilage. Only hyaline cartilages can undergo ossification (calcifications on x-ray). It occurs between the 
ages of 25-65y. These calcifications may be confused with foreign bodies of esophagus or larynx 
on x-rays. The hyaline laryngeal cartilages are: • Thyroid • Cricoid • Most of arytenoid. The elastic laryngeal cartilages are: • Epiglottis • Corniculate 523 
Sold by @itachibot • Cuneiform • Tip of arytenoid.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following cartilage has a signet ring shape?
questions.explanation: Cricoid cartilage resembles a signet ring. It has a wide posterior lamina and a thin anterior arch.

questions.question:
Question 9: The skeletal remains of a person were found in a nearby forest. The thyroid cartilage was 
identified and the thyroid angle measures ‰0 degrees. The deceased person can be deemed as 
a
questions.explanation: The thyroid angle measures ‰0 degrees (right-angled) in men. It is the angle between the two thyroid lamina in the midline. It depends on gender: • Men: ‰0 degrees (forms the prominent adam’s apple) • Women: 120 degrees.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is called cartilage of Santorini?
questions.explanation: Corniculate cartilage is also known as the cartilage of Santorini. Cuneiform cartilage is also known as the cartilage of Wrisberg.

questions.question:
Question 11: An E‹T surgeon is operating on the larynx of a patient and he approaches the arytenoid 
cartilage. Which of the following is false regarding the attachments of the arytenoid cartilage?
questions.explanation:
The apex of the arytenoid supports the corniculate cartilages. 524 
Sold by @itachibot The following are the attachments of the arytenoid: • Base - cricoid • Vocal process - vocal ligament • Muscular process - intrinsic muscles of larynx • Apex - corniculate cartilages.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is not involved in the closure of glottis?
questions.explanation:
The posterior cricoarytenoid opens the glottis as it is the only abductor of the vocal cord. All other 
muscles close the glottis.

questions.question:
Question 13: An opera singer presents with difficulty raising the pitch of her voice while singing. Which of 
the following muscles is likely to be affected?
questions.explanation:
Cricothyroid is likely to be affected. Cricothyroid and vocalis (internal part of thyroarytenoid) are the tensors of the vocal cord which 
help in raising the pitch of the voice. The external laryngeal nerve is the smaller, external branch. It descends on the larynx, beneath 
the sternothyroid muscle, to supply the cricothyroid muscle. The external branch functions to 
tense the vocal cords by activating the cricothyroid muscle, and increasing pitch.

questions.question:
Question 14: Žou are the E‹T resident examining a patient in the wards. On asking him to swallow you 
notice the larynx moves upwards. Which of the following muscles is not responsible for this 
movement?
questions.explanation:
The sternohyoid is not responsible for upward movement (elevation). It is a depressor of the 
larynx. The extrinsic muscles of the larynx can be elevators or depressors. Elevators: Primary elevators act directly as they are attached to the thyroid cartilage and include • Stylopharyngeus • Salpingopharyngeus • Palatopharyngeus • Thyrohyoid Secondary elevators act indirectly as they are attached to the hyoid bone and include • Mylohyoid (main) • Digastric • Stylohyoid 525 
Sold by @itachibot • Geniohyoid Depressors: • Sternohyoid • Sternothyroid • Omohyoid Easy to remember: Check the other attachment(non-laryngeal side). If it's above the level of the 
hyoid, the muscle is an elevator. If it's below the level of the hyoid, it’s a depressor.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is an intrinsic membrane of the larynx?
questions.explanation:
The cricothyroid membrane is an intrinsic membrane of the larynx as it connects laryngeal 
structures to each other. Extrinsic membranes and ligaments connect laryngeal structures with surrounding structures 
outside the laryngeal framework like the trachea or hyoid. These are: • Cricotracheal membrane • Thyrohyoid membrane • Hyoepiglottic ligament. Intrinsic membranes and ligaments connect laryngeal structures with each other. These are: • Cricovocal membrane • Quadrangular membrane • Cricothyroid ligament • Thyroepiglottic ligament. questions.question:
Question 16: 519 
Sold by @itachibot Following a road traffic accident, a 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department 
with maxillofacial trauma and inability to open the mouth. To establish an airway, an 
emergency laryngotomy is performed. Where is the opening made?
questions.explanation:
In laryngotomy, an opening is made on the cricothyroid membrane. Laryngotomy is also called cricothyrotomy or mini-tracheostomy. It is done as an emergency 
life-saving procedure to buy some time to allow a patient to be carried to the operation theatre. 
Once stable, it is replaced by intubation or tracheostomy. Most of the laryngeal foreign bodies are arrested above the vocal cords, i.e. above the middle of 
the thyroid cartilage. Thus, an effective airway can be provided by piercing the cricothyroid 
membrane. 526 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is not seen as part of the larynx?
questions.explanation: Labyrinth is seen in inner ear and not in larynx. The 2 mucosal folds within the larynx divide the larynx into 3 cavities: • Vestibule: Above the false/vestibular folds • Ventricle: Between the vestibular and vocal/true folds • Subglottis: Below the true folds Saccule an extension of ventricle is present in the paraglottic space.

questions.question:
Question 18: A surgeon is worried about the spread of laryngeal carcinoma to the pre-epiglottic space. 
Which of the following structures do not border this space?
questions.explanation:
Suprahyoid epiglottis does not form a boundary of the pre-epiglottic space. The infrahyoid 
epiglottis forms the posteromedial border. Two potential spaces within the larynx provide an avenue for the spread of tumors: • Pre-epiglottic space • Paraglottic space. The pre-epiglottic space is bounded: • Superiorly by the hyoepiglottic ligament • Anteriorly by the thyroid and thyrohyoid membrane • Posteromedially by the infrahyoid epiglottis and quadrangular membrane. The paraglottic space is bounded: • Laterally by thyroid • Medially by ventricle and quadrangular membrane 527 
Sold by @itachibot • Inferomedially by conus elasticus • Posteriorly by pyriform sinus.

questions.question:
Question 19: A 35-year-old smoker presents with hoarseness of voice. On laryngoscopy, there is edema of 
the Reinke’s space. Where is this space located?
questions.explanation:
Reinke’s space is seen in the glottis. It is a potential space underneath the epithelium of vocal 
cords. It contains scanty subepithelial connective tissue. Edema of this space is commonly seen in 
smokers and is called Reinke’s edema or smoker’s larynx. The laryngoscopy image below shows diffuse bilateral edema of the vocal folds or Reinke's edema. 528 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 20: Žou are performing a direct laryngoscopy procedure to enter the larynx and visualise the 
structures it contains. Which of the following structures form the inlet of the larynx?
questions.explanation: Aryepiglottic folds form the inlet of the larynx. The laryngeal inlet is an oblique opening with the following boundaries: • Anterior: Free margin of the epiglottis • Posterior: Interarytenoid fold • Sides: Aryepiglottic folds.

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following muscle causes opening of laryngeal inlet?

options.a: Most common cause of stridor in newborn

questions.explanation:
Thyroepiglotticus causes the opening of the laryngeal inlet. The intrinsic muscles of the larynx acting on the laryngeal inlet are: • Openers of laryngeal inlet • Thyroepiglottic • Closers of laryngeal inlet • Interarytenoid (oblique part). • Aryepiglottic (posterior oblique part of interarytenoids). 529 
Sold by @itachibot Stridor and Congenital Conditions of Larynx
